awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Compressive Robotic Systems: Gaining Efficiency Through Sparsity in Dynamic Environments
awd_abstract_narration:
This project investigates autonomous control and coordination of a group of robots that are tasked to explore, map, or monitor the environment they are in.  The project aims to enhance the capabilities of such a group of robots by integrating Compressive Sensing for data compression. Compressive sensing enables robots to quickly extract information from their environment, efficiently communicate that information to each other over a wireless network, and intelligently direct their motion to obtain relevant sensing data in the future.  Significant theoretical and technical challenges must be addressed in this project to realize the potential of a compressive robotic sensing system.  The project will demonstrate results in two specific applications, (i) driving a group of aerial robots to monitor their environment, (ii) driving robotic micro-probes to measure processes inside a living cell.  The project also seeks to disseminate its findings through educational and outreach activities.  Results will be incorporated into undergraduate and graduate level courses in control theory at both Boston University and Stanford University.  The researchers will also work with high school students and undergraduates through research mentorship programs and through lab demonstrations for visitors.

The fundamental goal of the project is to create rigorously analyzed algorithms that take advantage of sparse signal descriptions to create efficient motion plans for a team of sensing robots that monitor the environment.  The driving hypothesis is that sparsity can greatly extend the performance of robotic sensing systems by saving battery power, computation, storage, and communication bandwidth---all critically limited resources for robotic platforms.  The research team will take a Bayesian approach to Compressive Sensing, which allows for sensing quality to be quantified with information theoretic metrics such as entropy.  A receding horizon control approach will be developed for driving robotic sensors to collect the most valuable sensor data, in order to reconstruct a sparse representation of their environment using Compressive Sensing.  Such control strategies will be adapted to both static and dynamic environments, and both centralized and distributed solutions will be sought. The concepts developed in this project will be applied to two specific sensing domains: (i) networks of quadrotor sensing robots sensing environmental data and (ii) confocal fluorescence microscopy for three-dimensional imaging of dynamics in bio-molecular systems. These two application domains have radically different length and time scales, dynamical properties, and information content. A successful application of the ideas developed in this project to both these domains will prove the generality of the Compressive Robotic Sensing System concept.

por.por_cntn:
The central goal of this project was to provide a rigorous foundation for compressive robotic sensing systems that take advantage of the natural structure present in real-world signals to reduce the amount of sampling, computation, and communication needed to perform some given control task. The intellectual merit of the project was divided into two related but distinct efforts. Under the first, robotic mapping was used as a guiding example for exploring ways to reduce the amount of sampling needed without significantly reducing the quality of the final map produced. This idea was applied to measurements based on ultrasonic rangers and on LIDAR systems. The work with ultrasonic range sensors was tested through physical experiment and explored the use of different representations of the underlying signal and their efficacy in reconstructing the original signal from highly subsampled data. Our results indicated that even with low sampling ratios of the original signal, reasonable reconstructions could be created that accurately indicated the range to objects in the sensor?s range. Results with LIDAR were tested initially through simulations, allowing us to play with a large number of parameters and to do extensive testing to explore the impact of the number of measurements used as well as in how those measurements were acquired. We also explored how to measure the quality of a map produced since accurate rendering of the environment may not be the ultimate goal. We defined new metrics based on the ability of a planner to generate effective paths using the map, showing that even maps with significant artifacts generated by the reconstruction process can be used for efficient and effective path planning. The underlying assumption in that work was that the data represented an indoor, office-like environment. The ideas were then applied to three dimensional scans and tested on data captured both in indoor, structured environments and in outdoor, unstructured settings. Here we focused on reconstruction of the original data from a sparsely sampled version, showing that our methods outperformed simple interpolation. The second effort looked at systems that were sparse in space. These could represent, for example, a collection of specific targets in the environment that need to be visited or spatial fields that are homogenous over large regions and change rapidly in specific locations. The goal was to develop approaches to move efficiently through the environment, using only a small number of measurements, maintain a good quality estimate of the state of the entire system. While similar to Traveling Salesman Problems, the inclusion of an uncertainty that depended on the spatial location of measurements significantly complicated the problem. In addition to developing a theoretical structure describing the optimal approach (in terms of the uncertainty in the state estimates), we created heuristics that generated practical plans for acquiring data.

Broader impacts of this project include the training of three graduate students, one of which is a female student and one of which is from an underrepresented minority group, and four undergraduate students, two of which are female students. The project also supported participation in K-12 outreach activities, including lab tours for high students in the local Boston area, and in hosting four high school students for six week research internships in the lab through the Research Internships in Science and Engineering (RISE) program at Boston University.
